column4: I'm still curious what that privacy violation screennameguy was talking about
he didn't say - so please drop the topic
you unmount a file system - not a device file
I thought you could do it either way? (I realize that it's more technically correct to do sudo umount /media/directory, but doesn't sudo umount /dev/thePartition work too?)
mikejet: What's the word on the new 64 bit flash that was released for Linux, I remember reading an announcement in November about it
How is that beta 64 bit flash you mentioned? Worth using, or do you think it's best to hold off
it's interesting to use, but not mainstream ready
Cool, good to know... I use 64 bit on the desktop, but my desktop is more of a headless server these days than anything else, so Flash hasn't really been a significant concern
Would they still not be mountable if it were a hardware RAID?
they are not hardware from what he said

Ah, I missed that, somethingorigina if it's a software RAID, Ubuntu won't be any help... If you have essential files stored on a RAID-0 that's just a bad idea. Use 1 or 0+1 or something... As far as recovering your files, if they're that valuable you'll probably need a data recovery specialist or something

I don't really understand why people get indignant when they're told to go to #ubuntu+1 or #ubuntu-offtopic... Those channels aren't like, second-class channels for has-beens. They're there for a reason.
Is the native release actually released yet? Or is it still like alpha-beta'ish quality?
still beta (official stamp is beta I think)
very promising results so far, but not without issue
